title: Synthetic Recap
body:
ATLANTA (AP) — In a performance for the ages, Dikembe Mutombo didn’t just lead the Atlanta Hawks to victory; he single-handedly erected a fortress around the rim. The Hawks’ center delivered a historic and utterly dominant triple-double, propelling Atlanta to a 100-87 win over the Indiana Pacers.

The stat line was staggering: 10 points, a Herculean 27 rebounds, and a jaw-dropping 10 blocked shots. Mutombo was an impenetrable force, turning the paint into a no-fly zone. Every Pacer drive was met with the looming presence and wagging finger of the league’s premier defender. His 27 boards were an act of sheer will, controlling the game’s tempo and crushing Indiana’s spirit with every possession.

While Steve Smith provided the offensive spark with a game-high 27 points, this night belonged to Mutombo. His triple-double, built on the foundation of elite defense and rebounding, was the engine of the Hawks’ triumph. Christian Laettner added a quiet 18 points, but his contributions were secondary to the main event unfolding in the lane.

The Pacers, frustrated at every turn, were led by Reggie Miller’s 24 points. Yet even Miller’s sharpshooting couldn’t penetrate the defensive wall Mutombo built. The Hawks’ defense, anchored by its centerpiece, was simply overwhelming.

On this night in 1997, Dikembe Mutombo authored a masterpiece of defensive basketball. It was a performance that transcended the final score, a legendary effort that will be remembered not for how many points he scored, but for how many he prevented.
